title: 107_s1661
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Deadly Biological Agent Control Act of 2001". It pertains to the control of biological weapons. The "Deadly Biological Agent Control Act of 2001" amends Section 175 of title 18, United States Code, regarding Select Agents. It imposes penalties for possessing or transferring select agents without certification from the Department of Health and Human Services. The "Deadly Biological Agent Control Act of 2001" amends Section 175 of title 18, United States Code, imposing penalties for possessing or transferring select agents without certification from the Department of Health and Human Services. The act defines terms like biological agent, toxin, for use as a weapon, and select agent. The "Deadly Biological Agent Control Act of 2001" amends Section 175 of title 18, United States Code, to regulate select agents, which are biological agents or toxins listed under the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996. The Secretary, in consultation with other federal officials, controls the list of biological agents and toxins. The "Deadly Biological Agent Control Act of 2001" amends Section 175 of title 18, United States Code, to regulate select agents. General and Federal officials annually review and revise the list of select agents based on criteria such as human health effects, contagiousness, and transfer methods of biological agents or toxins. The Secretary prioritizes countermeasures, including vaccines and therapies, based on criteria such as availability, effectiveness, and potential use in bioterrorist attacks. Consultation with scientific experts is also required. The Secretary establishes standards for possession and use of biological agents and toxins to protect public health and prevent access to listed substances. The Secretary establishes standards and a certification process to prevent unauthorized access to biological agents and toxins for criminal purposes. Possession of listed substances is prohibited, except for specific entities like health or research organizations. The Department of Health and Human Services certifies legitimate health, research, or other entities for possessing biological agents or toxins for peaceful purposes. These entities must undergo periodic site inspections and enforce safety procedures. Enforcement of safety procedures includes proper training, laboratory facilities, and safeguards to prevent misuse of biological agents or toxins for terrorism or criminal purposes. Enforcement of safety procedures involves training, facilities, and safeguards to prevent misuse of biological agents for terrorism or criminal purposes, including diagnostic or verification purposes for entities possessing and transferring the agents. Any individual handling biological agents or toxins in a certified research facility must pass a criminal background check and be registered with the Department of Health and Human Services for the specific research project. Penalties apply for non-compliance. Any entity certified under this subsection allowing a restricted person to handle biological agents or toxins may face decertification and fines up to $500,000. Supervisory personnel knowingly permitting restricted individuals may also be penalized. Section 175b of title 18, United States Code, states that individuals who handle or access biological agents or toxins may face civil penalties up to $250,000 and imprisonment for up to 1 year. Additionally, under Section 511 of the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996, violators of subsections (e) or (f) may be subject to civil penalties of $250,000 for individuals and $500,000 for entities certified under subsection (f). Section 511 of the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 is amended to include "toxins" along with "agents" and "or toxin" after "agent" in subsection (e). The effective date of these amendments is the same as section 511. Section 511(e) of the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 is amended to include "toxins" along with "agents." The heading is changed to "Agents and Toxins." SEC. 3. INTERIM RULE.

The Secretary of Health and Human Services must issue an interim final rule within 30 days of this Act's enactment to implement section 511(d) of the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996. The rule will take effect 60 days after issuance, including for criminal and civil penalties. 

SEC. 4. REGISTRATION OF BIOLOGICAL AGENTS AND TOXINS. Research facilities possessing listed biological agents or toxins must submit a certification application within 30 days of the promulgation of the interim final rule under section 3.
